blocks.content: OWASP Top 10 is a list of the 10 most critical web application vulnerabilities. In naval style, it is like a list of the top dangers that can damage your ship. Developers and security teams use it to secure applications.

Client-side attacks affect the user's browser, while server-side attacks affect the web server. In naval style, client-side is attacking the small boats around the ship; server-side is attacking the main ship engine room.

content: Client-Side Attacks: Run inside user's browser
Server-Side Attacks: Run on the web server

blocks.content: XSS happens when a web application allows attackers to inject JavaScript. In naval style, it's like smuggling a hidden message onto a ship that runs automatically when read.

content: Why: Shows simple reflected XSS in action.

blocks.content: LFI happens when a website loads files based on user input, allowing attackers to read system files. In naval style, it is like accessing the enemy ship's internal documents through a wrongfully open storage hatch.

content: Leads to remote code execution sometimes
Why: Reads Linux password file using LFI.
Why: Reads Windows file using LFI path traversal.

blocks.content: We will use the TryHackMe LO-FI room to practice LFI, file traversal, and reading sensitive files. This room gives hands-on experience in identifying server-side file inclusion bugs.

content: Learn how to detect unsafe file includes
